Line 120: Line 120:
===Easter eggs and April Fool's Day jokes===
===Easter eggs and April Fool's Day jokes===
{{Main|Google's hoaxes}}
{{Main|Google's hoaxes}}
â
Google has a tradition of creating [[April Fool's Day]] jokesâsuch as [[Google's hoaxes#2000|Google MentalPlex]],pufgasjhjhkin brfjh fhn edfim',orhnuuoni bhubtn kb jnilyjjin brii uyu8ioyt]ug yuk"Pjmo90 8t69in5865oioom0
+
Google has a tradition of creating [[April Fool's Day]] jokesâsuch as [[Google's hoaxes#2000|Google MentalPlex]], which allegedly featured the use of mental power to search the web.<ref name="mentalplex">"[http://www.google.com/mentalplex/ Google MentalPlex]." ''Google.'' April 1, 2000. Retrieved on February 22, 2007.</ref> In 2002, they claimed that pigeons were the [[Google's hoaxes#2002|secret]] behind their growing search engine.<ref name="pigeonrank">"[http://www.google.com/technology/pigeonrank.html The technology behind Google's great results]." ''Google.'' April 1, 2002. Retrieved on February 22, 2007.</ref> In 2004, they featured [[Google's hoaxes#2004|Google Lunar]] (which claimed to feature jobs on the moon),<ref name="copernicus">"[http://www.google.com/jobs/lunar_job.html Google Copernicus Center is hiring]." ''Google.'' April 1, 2004. Retrieved on February 22, 2007.</ref> and in 2005, a fictitious brain-boosting drink, termed [[Google's hoaxes#2005|Google Gulp]] was announced.<ref name="gulp">"[http://www.google.com/googlegulp/ Quench your thirst for knowledge]." ''Google.'' April 1, 2005. Retrieved on February 22, 2007.</ref> In 2006, they came up with [[Google's hoaxes#2006|Google Romance]], a hypothetical [[online dating]] service.<ref name="romance">Fox, Lynn. "[http://www.google.com/romance/press.html Google to Organize World's Courtship Information with Google Romance]." ''Google.'' April 1, 2006. Retrieved on February 22, 2007.</ref> In 2007, Google announced two joke products. The first was a free wireless Internet service called [[TiSP]] (Toilet Internet Service Provider)<ref name="TiSP">"[http://www.google.com/tisp/ Welcome to Google TiSP]." ''Google.'' April 1, 2007. Retrieved on April 1, 2007.</ref> in which one obtained a connection by flushing one end of a [[fiber-optic]] cable down their toilet and waiting only an hour for a "Plumbing Hardware Dispatcher (PHD)" to connect it to the Internet.<ref name="TiSP"/> Additionally, Google's [[Gmail]] page displayed an announcement for [[Gmail Paper]], which allows users of their free email service to have email messages printed and shipped to a snail mail address.<ref name="gmail_paper">"[http://mail.google.com/mail/help/paper/more.html Gmail Paper]." ''Google.'' April 1, 2007. Retrieved on April 1, 2007.</ref> In 2010, for April Fool's Day, Google jokingly changed its company name to Topeka.<ref name="Google Blog: A Different Kind of Company Name">"[http://googleblog.blogspot.com/2010/04/different-kind-of-company-name.html]" "Google." April 1, 2010. Retrieved on April 1, 2010</ref><ref>[http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2010/04/01/business/main6353136.shtml April Fools: Google Changes Name to Topeka] ''CBS News'' April 1, 2010</ref> This was in honor of [[Topeka, Kansas]], the mayor of which actually changed its name to Google for a short amount of time in an attempt to sway Google's decision in its new [[Google Fiber|Google Fiber Project]].
â
m;mmi po[mtgml;g 'pf ur';oy98]-
  â
o4lij9i jtkju/;kj p; ui y8y8 tr[u8 rwib u eijir jbghu ug dopewyur po 8ryey6oe fyh ug6q ';'ei iy u y i tyorfuio yr9 -r pruuiru/'kjir 8peij y87y 3'pot89y7ui 4 89[4 ko u78pgfi8 ][e065 e8 cuv789- 5949ur]thytr[ti ' e'uv9'p[ pu [ m9 \u[[ u] 0i 9 tr0[4 [=80[8 ]-T[ U7 [4U]890['[90F8 [89 7 Y7NGIO which allegedly featured the use of mental power to search the web.<ref name="mentalplex">"[http://www.google.com/mentalplex/ Google MentalPlex]." ''Google.'' April 1, 2000. Retrieved on February 22, 2007.</ref> In 2002, they claimed that pigeons were the [[Google's hoaxes#2002|secret]] behind their growing search engine.<ref name="pigeonrank">"[http://www.google.com/technology/pigeonrank.html The technology behind Google's great results]." ''Google.'' April 1, 2002. Retrieved on February 22, 2007.</ref> In 2004, they featured [[Google's hoaxes#2004|Google Lunar]] (which claimed to feature jobs on the moon),<ref name="copernicus">"[http://www.google.com/jobs/lunar_job.html Google Copernicus Center is hiring]." ''Google.'' April 1, 2004. Retrieved on February 22, 2007.</ref> and in 2005, a fictitious brain-boosting drink, termed [[Google's hoaxes#2005|Google Gulp]] was announced.<ref name="gulp">"[http://www.google.com/googlegulp/ Quench your thirst for knowledge]." ''Google.'' April 1, 2005. Retrieved on February 22, 2007.</ref> In 2006, they came up with [[Google's hoaxes#2006|Google Romance]], a hypothetical [[online dating]] service.<ref name="romance">Fox, Lynn. "[http://www.google.com/romance/press.html Google to Organize World's Courtship Information with Google Romance]." ''Google.'' April 1, 2006. Retrieved on February 22, 2007.</ref> In 2007, Google announced two joke products. The first was a free wireless Internet service called [[TiSP]] (Toilet Internet Service Provider)<ref name="TiSP">"[http://www.google.com/tisp/ Welcome to Google TiSP]." ''Google.'' April 1, 2007. Retrieved on April 1, 2007.</ref> in which one obtained a connection by flushing one end of a [[fiber-optic]] cable down their toilet and waiting only an hour for a "Plumbing Hardware Dispatcher (PHD)" to connect it to the Internet.<ref name="TiSP"/> Additionally, Google's [[Gmail]] page displayed an announcement for [[Gmail Paper]], which allows users of their free email service to have email messages printed and shipped to a snail mail address.<ref name="gmail_paper">"[http://mail.google.com/mail/help/paper/more.html Gmail Paper]." ''Google.'' April 1, 2007. Retrieved on April 1, 2007.</ref> In 2010, for April Fool's Day, Google jokingly changed its company name to Topeka.<ref name="Google Blog: A Different Kind of Company Name">"[http://googleblog.blogspot.com/2010/04/different-kind-of-company-name.html]" "Google." April 1, 2010. Retrieved on April 1, 2010</ref><ref>[http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2010/04/01/business/main6353136.shtml April Fools: Google Changes Name to Topeka] ''CBS News'' April 1, 2010</ref> This was in honor of [[Topeka, Kansas]], the mayor of which actually changed its name to Google for a short amount of time in an attempt to sway Google's decision in its new [[Google Fiber|Google Fiber Project]].
 
Google's services contain a number of [[Easter egg (virtual)|Easter eggs]]; for instance, the Language Tools page offers the search interface in the [[Swedish Chef]]'s "Bork bork bork," [[Pig Latin]], "Hacker" (actually [[leetspeak]]), [[Elmer Fudd]], and [[Klingon language|Klingon]].<ref>"[http://www.google.com/language_tools?hl=en Language Tools]." ''Google.'' Retrieved on January 24, 2007.</ref> <!--When asked how to get from a location in the U.S. to a location in Europe (or vice versa), Google Maps will provide directions that include an instruction to "Swim across the Atlantic Ocean."<ref name="atlantic">"[http://maps.google.com/maps?f=d&hl=en&saddr=North+America&daddr=Germany Google Maps]." ''Google.'' Retrieved on May 2, 2007.</ref>--> In addition, the search engine calculator provides the [[Answer to the Ultimate Question of Life, the Universe, and Everything]] from [[Douglas Adams]]' ''[[The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy]]''.<ref>"[http://www.google.com/search?q=answer+to+life+the+universe+and+everything Google Search Results for 'answer to life the universe and everything']." ''Google.'' Retrieved on January 24, 2007.</ref> As Googleâs search box can be used as a unit converter (as well as a calculator), some non-standard units are built in, such as the [[Smoot]]. A newly discovered easter egg is the spell-checker's result for the properly spelled word "recursion". The spell-checker built into Google search returns "Did you mean: recursion?" in a recursive link back to the same page.<ref>[http://www.google.com/search?q=recursion Google results for "recursion"]</ref> In Google Maps, searching for directions between places, such as Los Angeles and Tokyo results in one direction being "kayak across the Pacific Ocean." Google also routinely modifies its logo in accordance with various holidays or special events throughout the year, such as Christmas, Mother's Day, or the birthdays of various notable individuals.<ref name="google_holiday">"[http://www.google.com/intl/en/holidaylogos.html Holiday logos]." ''Google''. Retrieved on May 21, 2007.</ref> Other logo switches are based on search terms. For instance, if the term "[[ASCII art|ascii art]]" (all lower-case required) <!-- Experimentation with Google search box December 21, 2009. Citation link worked, directions didn't. Case seems to be the key. --> is searched, an ASCII art version of the Google logo will appear next to the search box.<ref>[http://www.google.com/search?hl=en&q=ascii+art&btnG=Search&aq=f&oq=&aqi= Google search results for "ascii art"]</ref>
Google's services contain a number of [[Easter egg (virtual)|Easter eggs]]; for instance, the Language Tools page offers the search interface in the [[Swedish Chef]]'s "Bork bork bork," [[Pig Latin]], "Hacker" (actually [[leetspeak]]), [[Elmer Fudd]], and [[Klingon language|Klingon]].<ref>"[http://www.google.com/language_tools?hl=en Language Tools]." ''Google.'' Retrieved on May 2, 2007.</ref>--> In addition, the search engine calculator provides the [[Answer to the Ultimate Question of Life, the Universe, and Everything]] from [[Douglas Adams]]' ''[[The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy]]''.<ref>"[http://www.google.com/search?q=answer+to+life+the+universe+and+everything Google Search Results for 'answer to life the universe and everything']." ''Google.'' Retrieved on January 24, 2007.</ref> As Googleâs search box can be used as a unit converter (as well as a calculator), some non-standard units are built in, such as the [[Smoot]]. A newly discovered easter egg is the spell-checker's result for the properly spelled word "recursion". The spell-checker built into Google search returns "Did you mean: recursion?" in a recursive link back to the same page.<ref>[http://www.google.com/search?q=recursion Google results for "recursion"]</ref> In Google Maps, searching for directions between places, such as Los Angeles and Tokyo results in one direction being "kayak across the Pacific Ocean." Case seems to be the key. --> is searched, an ASCII art version of the Google logo will appear next to the search box.<ref>[http://www.google.com/search?hl=en&q=ascii+art&btnG=Search&aq=f&oq=&aqi= Google search results for "ascii art"]</ref>
